thread.title: Viewers fall in love on Further Back in Time for Dinner | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Viewers fall in love on Further Back in Time for Dinner | Daily Mail Online

author: Jo Tweedy For Mailonline
title: Viewers fall in love on Further Back in Time for Dinner | Daily Mail Online
text: Share this article Share Debbie was relieved of her duties at the episode's end to show how domestic service roles became less common as war looked imminent. The news that Debbie would no longer be a feature in the Robshaw house caused a flurry of tweets on social media. ‏@SewWhite wrote: 'Further back in time for dinner should be called the Debbie show! She's amazing!' @TheVintageYear added: 'Debbie hasn't cooked it so I don't want it.' @_Poots_ added: 'Fred is in love with Debbie, isn't he? I don't blame him, I'm in love with Debbie too.' Debbie showed off her culinary prowess in the Robshaw's early 20th century kitchen where dishes included calves' brains, wood pigeon and liver The Robshaw family are back in a new series of Back In Time for Dinner this time dubbed Further Back in Time for Dinner. Pictured: Debbie pours the tea for (l-r) Rosalind, Miranda, Brandon, Rochelle and Fred Fan favourite Rochelle Robshaw was forced to join Debbie in the kitchen in last night's episode to show how employer's were forced to try and make their servants lives easier as domestic service roles dwindled. Right, Debbie made short work of the wood pigeon, while a squeamish Rochelle looked on The upper hand: an efficient Debbie kept Rochelle in check in the kitchen The plaudits kept coming: ‏@Em_Bittered penned: 'Debbie is without doubt the DON of #FurtherBackInTimeForDinner She bloody owned that pigeon.' ‏@SheldonB14 wrote: 'Debbie has plucked, gutted and prepped the pigeon while Rochelle still hasn't lit the gas. Bet she's fun though. #BackinTimeforDinner' Meanwhile, watching from home was Debbie herself, the young catering graduate said on Twitter her mother found her daughter's on-screen presence hilarious. She wrote: @deb_raw: 'Mum is laughing so hard at further back in time for dinner. She's not gonna have any lungs left by the end.' Further Back In Time For Dinner has seen the family taken right back to the 1900s – a world of corsets and calves’ brains – and runs up to 1949, where the first series began. Effectively, this means the Robshaws will have eaten their way through every decade of the last century, having previously munched in every decade of the latter half of the 20th century. Read more: Share or comment on this article 146
